entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:32AM EDT until August 9 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
FFWLWX
The National Weather Service in Sterling Virginia has extended the
* Flash Flood Warning for... Western Albemarle County in central Virginia... Nelson County in central Virginia... Southeastern Augusta County in western Virginia... The Southeastern City of Staunton in western Virginia... The City of Waynesboro in western Virginia...
* Until 400 AM EDT.
* At 132 AM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Between 2 and 5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 3 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly.
HAZARD...Flash flooding caused by thunderstorms.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Flash flooding of small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses as well as other poor drainage and low-lying areas.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Staunton... Waynesboro... Stuarts Draft... Crozet... Grottoes... Crimora... Sherando... Shipman... Schuyler... Free Union... Wintergreen... Afton... Montebello... Fishersville... Lyndhurst... Nellysford... Ivy... Greenville... New Hope... Arrington...
This includes the following Flood Prone Roads... Route 776 near Route 667, West Leigh Drive/Leigh Way at Little Ivy Creek, Old Ballard Road at Ivy Creek, Ivy Road at Ivy Creek, Three Notchd Road at Route 680, Route 675 at Route 614, Route 614 along Moorman's River, Route 810 near Moorman's River, Route 671 at Moorman's River, Route 29/Red Hill Rd at N Fork Hardware River, Route 631 near North Fork Hardware River, Route 20/Route 708 at North Fork Hardware River, Plank Road at Eppes Creek, Plank Road at South Fork Hardware River, Esmont Road along Ballinger Creek, Route 723 near Route 6 at Green Creek, Esmont Road at Totier Creek, Fortune Lane at Totier Creek, Glendower Road at Miller Creek, Route 6 near Totier Creek, Route 737 near Totier Creek, Route 602 at Green Creek, Patton Farm Road at South River, Creekside Mobile Home Park, Route 610 in Sherando at Back Creek, Route 250 at Desper Hollow Road, Route 610 at Route 634, Roseland Road and Virginia 56, Route 617 near Buck Creek, Davis Creek Lane near Davis Creek, Cub Creek Road near Route 56, Route 56 near Campbells Creek Drive, Highway 635 at North Fork of the Rockfish River, Kirby Avenue, 10th St and Jackson Avenue in Waynesboro and A Street at Steele Run.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:29AM EDT until August 9 at 5:30AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
FFWCHS
The National Weather Service in Charleston has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Berkeley County in southeastern South Carolina... Charleston County in southeastern South Carolina... Dorchester County in southeastern South Carolina...
* Until 530 AM EDT.
* At 129 AM EDT, Doppler radar numerous showers and thunderstorms with torrential rainfall impacting much of Berkeley and Dorchester Counties and extending into parts of central and upper Charleston County. As much a 2 to 5 inches of rain has fallen in this area since late Thursday evening on top of the 9 to 17 inches of rain that has fallen over the past several days. Widespread dangerous flash flooding is ongoing across the city of Moncks Corner. High water rescues are in progress and a life threatening situation is developing. Take action now. Renewed flash flood could develop across other parts of Dorchester County as well as central and upper Charleston County.
FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY for Moncks Corner. This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW!
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! Life threatening flash flooding of low water crossings, small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... North Charleston, Summerville, Goose Creek, Hanahan, Moncks Corner, Saint George, Naval Weapons Station Charleston, Ladson, Givhans Ferry State Park and Dorchester.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Berkeley, SC; Charleston, SC; Dorchester, SC

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:23AM EDT until August 9 at 9:00AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following counties, Allendale, Hampton and Jasper.
* WHEN...Until 900 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several structures are flooded and some sand bagging operations are continuing. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 122 AM EDT, flooding continued to occur in many areas. Between 7 and 13 inches of rain have fallen in the past several days. Additional rainfall amounts should average less than a half inch through mid-morning. - Emergency officials report numerous roads remain closed due to high water or are washed out. Homes are flooded in some areas. Flooding will continue along various creeks and streams and could worsen in some locations as water continues to move toward main stem rivers. Listen to local emergency management officials concerning any possible evacuations in your area. Heed any evacuation orders. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Bluffton, Ridgeland, Allendale, Hampton, Yemassee, Lake Warren State Park, Bellinger Hill Area, Jasper, Hardeeville and Varnville.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Allendale, SC; Hampton, SC; Jasper, SC

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 9 AM EDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:22AM EDT until August 9 at 8:45AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of southeast Georgia, including the following counties, Bulloch, Effingham, Jenkins and Screven and southeast South Carolina, including the following county, Allendale.
* WHEN...Until 845 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several structures are flooded and some sand bagging operations are continuing. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 121 AM EDT, flooding continued to occur in many areas. As much as 7 to 12 inches of rain has fallen across interior Southeast Georgia over the past several days. Additional rainfall amounts should average less than a quarter of an inch through mid-morning. - Emergency officials report numerous roads remain closed due to high water or are washed out. Homes are flooded in some areas. Flooding will continue along various creeks and streams which could worsen in some locations as water continues to move toward main stem rivers. A number of small dams have either failed or could fail over the coming days. Listen to local emergency management officials concerning any possible evacuations in your area. Heed any evacuation orders. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Statesboro, Millen, Sylvania, Springfield, Butts, Rincon, Port Wentworth, Guyton, Brooklet and Portal.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bulloch, GA; Effingham, GA; Jenkins, GA; Screven, GA; Allendale, SC

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:21AM EDT until August 10 at 11:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Baltimore MD/Washington DC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in West Virginia...
Opequon Creek near Martinsburg affecting Berkeley and Jefferson Counties.
For the Opequon Creek...including Martinsburg...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Opequon Creek near Martinsburg.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 12.5 feet, The creek is well out of its banks with lowlands nearby flooded. Golf Course Road /County Road 36/ is flooded near the Van Metre Ford Pedestrian Bridge. Fields and backyards near the creek are flooded and some residents may need to move items to higher ground. Several other roads are flooded, including Grapevine Road, Douglas Grove Road, and Paynes Ford Road. Backwater flooding is occurring on small tributaries, including Tuscarora Creek.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:30 AM EDT Friday the stage was 8.3 feet, or 1.7 feet below flood stage. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early this morning to a crest of 13.0 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 13.0 feet on 02/13/1985. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 1:04AM EDT until August 9 at 2:45AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following counties, Berkeley, Charleston, Colleton and Dorchester.
* WHEN...Until 245 AM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Several structures are flooded and some sand bagging operations are continuing. Numerous roads remain closed due to flooding. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1255 AM EDT, Flooding continues across portions of Colleton, Dorchester, Berkeley and Charleston Counties. Radar showed numerous showers and thunderstorms with torrential rainfall impacting much of the Charleston Tri-County area and Colleton County. The storms are moving east and northeast and will continue to move across much of the warned areas early this morning. Between 9 and 17 inches of rain have fallen in the last several days with 2 to 4 inches having fallen in some areas since late Thursday evening. Additional amounts up to 2 inches can be expected in spots, especially over Charleston, Dorchester and Berkeley Counties. While flooding is ongoing in many areas, this locally heavy rainfall could temporarily worsen flooding in some locations. Pay attention to water levels and be prepared to act if additional flood waters threaten your location.
- Emergency officials report numerous roads remain closed due to high water or are washed out. Homes are flooded in some areas. Flooding will continue along various creeks and streams and could worsen this evening where additional rainfall occurs.
Water levels along French Quarter Creek near Huger in Berkeley County remain in the major flood category and a number of homes are flooded along the creek. This includes areas along French Quarter Creek Road. Avoid this area. Water levels may actually rise slightly early this morning as these showers and thunderstorms push through.
Water levels at Ireland Creek at Walterboro are just below the moderate flood stage and may remain there through sunrise. Water will continue to impact some businesses and home along Ivanhoe Road between Forest Hills Road and Lands End Road.
Water levels along the Ashley River are slowly rising and may begin to flood nearby neighborhoods including the Ashborough neighborhood. Water had already entered the backyards of home along Mayfield Street and Lakeview Drive in the Ashborough neighborhood as of Thursday evening.
- Some locations that will experience flooding include... North Charleston, Mount Pleasant, Summerville, Goose Creek, Hanahan, Moncks Corner, Walterboro, Saint George, McClellanville and Edisto Beach.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Berkeley, SC; Charleston, SC; Colleton, SC; Dorchester, SC

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 9 at 12:53AM EDT until August 9 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...A portion of piedmont North Carolina, including the following county, Rowan.
* WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to N Second Creek, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1245 AM EDT, N Second Creek continues to rise above Action/Advisory Stage following storm-total rainfall of 3-5 inches resulting from Tropical Cyclone Debby. Nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas between Mount Ulla and Woodleaf is ongoing. It may take a few more hours for N Second Creek to crest and it will likely not fall back below Action/Advisory Stage until later Friday morning or early Friday afternoon. Therefore, the Flood Advisory has been extended to account for continuing nuisance flood conditions along N Second Creek.
- The following streamgauge is above Action/Advisory Stage, resulting in nuisance flooding along North Second Creek..
ID: BRBN7 NAME: above Statesville Blvd (US 70), 4 mi S of Woodleaf CURRENT STAGE: 12.84 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 12.0 feet MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 14.0 feet TREND: Rising Slowly IMPACTS: N Second Creek is out of its banks up and downstream of the gauge site on US 70, flooding adjacent farmland and other low-lying areas with up to 2 feet of inundation. Woodleaf Rd is likely flooding. In fast-response situations, upstream tributaries will likely already be flooding several low-water crossings. Impacted crossings upstream may include at White Rd, Lyerly Rd, Upright Rd, Graham Rd, Hall Rd, Childers Rd, and Bear Poplar Rd.
ESTIMATED FORECAST: N Second Creek will continue to rise slowly overnight and is expected to crest below 13 and 13.3 feet overnight tonight before beginning a gradual recession early Friday morning.
- Some locations that may continue to experience flooding include... Cleveland, Woodleaf and Mount Ulla.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 2 PM EDT THIS AFTERNOON

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 9 at 12:53AM EDT until August 9 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents are expected. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 7 to 8 feet expected in the surf zone.
* WHERE...Accomack and Northampton Counties.
* WHEN...For the Beach Hazards Statement, through this evening. For the High Surf Advisory, from 6 AM this morning to 7 PM EDT this evening.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Large breaking waves will result in rough surf conditions and a high risk of rip currents. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 9 at 12:43AM EDT until August 9 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Nuisance flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Eastern Chester County, South Carolina
* WHEN...Until 800 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to Fishing Creek and Rocky Creek including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1242 AM EDT, The Rocky Creek and Fishing Creek watersheds are continuing to deal with significant flows following 2-5 inches of rainfall from Tropical Cyclone Debby. While no additional rainfall is expected, Rocky Creek and Fishing Creek will remain above Action/Advisory Stage for the next several hours, resulting in nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas. A Flood Advisory will remain in effect through at least 8:00AM to allow these streams to crest and recede below bankfull levels.
Please avoid all flooded roadways and obey all barricades. Numerous roadways were closed across Chester County earlier today. Even if the roads are no longer flooded, erosion beneath the road surface may have compromised the road and could cause it to collapse under the weight of a vehicle. Turn around and find an alternative route.
- Nuisance flooding may continue near the following areas... Great Falls, Richburg, and Edgemoor.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 9 at 12:40AM EDT until August 9 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Nuisance flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Central and southern York County, South Carolina
* WHEN...Until 800 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1238 AM EDT, The Allison Creek and Fishing Creek watersheds are continuing to deal with significant flows following 5-7 inches of rainfall from Tropical Cyclone Debby. While no additional rainfall is expected, Allison Creek, Wildcat Creek, and Fishing Creek will remain above Action/Advisory Stage into early Friday morning, resulting in nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas. A Flood Advisory will remain in effect through at least 8:00 AM to allow these streams to crest and recede below bankfull levels.
Please avoid all flooded roadways and obey all barricades. Even if the roads are no longer flooded, erosion beneath the road surface may have compromised the road and could cause it to collapse under the weight of a vehicle. Turn around and find an alternative route.
- Nuisance flooding may continue near the following areas... Rock Hill, York, Clover, Newport, Lesslie, Edgemoor and Bethany.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 AM EDT THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 9 at 12:36AM EDT until August 9 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Minor flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...The Rocky River in Cabarrus County, North Carolina.
* WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Common, deeper flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to area streams is ongoing with lesser impacts to vulnerable property. Expect extensive flooding of farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Inundation may be several feet deep. Several low-water crossings, roads, and bridges may be flooded and impassible, with deeper flows over roadways possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1234 AM EDT, Storm-total rainfall of 4-6 inches from Tropical Cyclone Debby has resulted in significant rises along the Rocky River in Cabarrus County. Tributaries feeding the Rocky River have crested and are gradually receding below Action/Advisory Stage, but the resultant floodwaves are now moving through the Rocky River, resulting in very significant rises along the Rocky River from Harrisburg to Georgeville to Midland. These rises have resulted in high-end Minor flooding with extensive impacts to low-lying areas adjacent to the river. The Rocky River may not crest for a few more hours and it will likely not fall back below Minor Flood Stage until Friday afternoon. Therefore, a Flood Warning will remain in effect through later Friday to allow the Rocky River to crest and recede below critical levels.
- The following streamgauge is above Minor Flood Stage, resulting in Minor flooding along the Rocky River from Harrisburg to Georgeville...
ID: IBFN7 NAME: above Irish Buffalo Creek, 5 W Georgeville CURRENT STAGE: 24.23 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 12.0 feet MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 16.5 feet MODERATE FLOOD STAGE: 26 feet TREND: Cresting.
ESTIMATED FORECAST and IMPACTS: The Rocky River is currently cresting near 24.3 feet. A reasonable worst case crest of 24.5 feet cannot be ruled out by 2:00AM. At these levels, flooding is occurring near and over the intersection of Mt Pleasant Rd and NC 200 with extensive flooding of farmland and other low-lying areas along NC 200. Floodwaters are approaching and possibly flooding NC 200 with backwater effects flooding Parks Lafferty Rd. Floodwaters may also approach a driveway to a care facility at the 5300 block of NC 200, restricting access to the facility.
- The Rocky River is flooding areas near the following locations... Harrisburg, Mt Pleasant, Georgeville, and Midland.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 8:02PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality and the Lane Regional Air Protection Agency has continued an Air Quality Advisory for eastern Lane County, which is in effect until 1 PM PDT Friday.
An Air Quality Advisory for smoke remains in effect. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels at times through 1 PM PDT Friday.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate heart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
More information about air quality can be found at: www.orcaa.org www.swcleanair.gov www.oregon.gov/DEQ www.lrapa.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lane County Cascade Foothills; Cascades of Lane County

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM PDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 8:02PM PDT by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
The Southwest Clean Air Agency has issued an Air Quality Advisory, which is in effect until 1 PM PDT Friday.
An Air Quality Advisory for Smoke has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels due to smoke at times through 1 PM PDT Friday.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes, runny nose, aggravate heart and lung diseases, and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
More information about air quality can be found at: www.orcaa.org www.swcleanair.gov www.oregon.gov/DEQ www.lrapa.org
entry.cap:areaDesc: Cowlitz County Lowlands; East Clark County Lowlands; South Washington Cascade Foothills; West Columbia River Gorge - SR 14; Central Columbia River Gorge - SR 14; South Washington Cascades

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 8 at 10:02PM EDT until August 9 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of southeast South Carolina, including the following areas, Charleston, Coastal Colleton, Dorchester, Inland Berkeley, Inland Colleton and Tidal Berkeley.
* WHEN...Until 8 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Low-water crossings may be flooded. Storm drains and ditches may become clogged with debris. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rainfall associated with departing Tropical Depression Debby may still occur at times tonight. Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches are possible across portions of South Carolina. This is on top of the excessive rainfall that has already fallen during the past 3 days, which could result in additional flash flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Colleton; Dorchester; Inland Berkeley; Coastal Colleton; Charleston; Tidal Berkeley

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:57PM EDT until August 9 at 7:00AM EDT by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring.
* WHERE...Portions of south central, southwest, and west central Virginia, including the following counties and independent cities, in south central Virginia, City of Danville, City of Martinsville, Henry and Pittsylvania. In southwest Virginia, Patrick. In west central Virginia, Franklin.
* WHEN...Until 700 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Numerous roads remain impassible due to flooding, and are likely to remain so overnight as water will be slow to recede.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 952 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain has exited the area, with only light to moderate rainfall remaining. Multiple roads remain flooded and impassible due to rainfall amounts between 2 and locally 5 inches that fell this afternoon and evening. - This includes the following streams and drainages... Banister River, Ararat River, Anglin Branch, Allen Creek, Archies Creek and Back Creek. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Danville, Martinsville, Rocky Mount, Altavista, Stuart, Hurt and Chatham. - This includes the following locations... The Martinsville Speedway, Martinsville Airport and Danville Airport. - For flooding safety information, please visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of northern New Hampshire, including the following areas, Northern Carroll, Northern Coos, Northern Grafton and Southern Coos.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued August 8 at 9:54PM EDT until August 9 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Lawsons Fork Creek in eastern Spartanburg County, South Carolina
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to Lawsons Fork Creek, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, and golf courses. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways and driveways is possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 952 PM EDT, Heavy rain has ended across Spartanburg County and Tropical Cyclone Debby has departed the area. However, Lawson's Fork Creek remains elevated above Action/Advisory Stage, causing nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas, including near Lake Forest Dr and the Country Club of Spartanburg. Lawsons Fork Creek will likely crest between 14 and 15 feet before midnight, then begin a gradual recession overnight, falling below Action/Advisory Stage by Friday morning. Therefore, expect nuisance flood conditions to persist into the early morning hours. The Flood Advisory will remain in effect until the flood threat has passed.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:33PM EDT until August 11 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Satilla River At Waycross affecting Pierce and Ware Counties.
Satilla River At Atkinson affecting Brantley County.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Satilla River at Waycross.
* WHEN...Until Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Flooding of agriculture and timberlands begins. On the Ware County side, the Jamestown Road Boat Ramp is flooded. On the Pierce/Brantley county line at the State Road 121 Bridge the boat ramp and dirt access roads are flooded. At 17.0 feet, On the Ware County side, the Jamestown Road Boat Ramp parking lot and access road is flooded and Simmons Trail is flooded cutting off one residence. On the Pierce County side, the Okefenokee Country Club Course Holes 14 through 16 begin to flood. At 18.0 feet, On the Pierce County side, the Okefenokee Country Club Golf Course is generally closed. Riverwoods Drive low lying properties begin to flood. At 20.0 feet, Effects railroad bridge. Rail traffic must be rerouted. On the Pierce County side, low lying roads are flooded and homes are threatened in the Riverwoods Drive community and in the Okefenokee Country Club.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 18.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 18.2 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:32PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Doctortown affecting Wayne and Long Counties.
Altamaha River At Baxley affecting Appling, Toombs, Wayne and Tattnall Counties.
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Georgia...
Altamaha River At Everett City affecting Wayne, McIntosh and Glynn Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Altamaha River at Everett City.
* WHEN...From late tonight until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Agricultural and timber lands near the river are flooded. At 13.0 feet, Water begins to encroach upon Altamaha Regional Park in Glynn County. This includes Altamaha Park Road, Betty Lott Lane and Bee Tree Island Road. In McIntosh County, Barrington Park at the end of Harper Lake Road begins to flood. Blue Reach Road also begins to flood near the Long County line. At 14.0 feet, Portions of Altamaha Regional Park become inundated, including the park campground, boat ramps and parking lots. Bee Tree Island Road is flooded and closed. The end of Betty Lott Lane is flooded and homes become cut off. At 15.0 feet, In Glynn County, the majority of Altamaha Regional Park becomes inundated, including water flowing across sections of Altamaha Park Road and Pennick Road. The Altamaha Regional Park is subject to closure at this level. Homes in the vicinity of the park are cut off by flood waters at this level, but elevated structures are not flooded. In McIntosh County, much of Barrington Park is underwater. Plum Orchard Road begins to flood. At 16.5 feet, In McIntosh County, water will approach a few elevated homes on Barrington Ferry Road, possibly restricting access.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:15 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 12.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tonight and continue rising to a crest of 14.5 feet early Saturday afternoon. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:21PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Hildreth On U.S. 129 Bridge affecting Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River near High Springs affecting Columbia and Alachua Counties.
Santa Fe River At Fort White affecting Columbia and Gilchrist Counties.
Santa Fe River Near O'Leno State Park affecting Columbia and Alachua Counties.
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Santa Fe River Near Worthington Springs affecting Alachua and Union Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River near O'Leno State Park.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 41.0 feet, Swimming becomes dangerous in the river in the park area. At 42.0 feet, Boat ramp at the end of Bible Camp Road begins to flood. At 43.0 feet, Access to river gage becomes limited as the Bible Camp Road boat ramp becomes flooded and the last half mile of Bible Camp Road begins to flood in Columbia County. Overland flooding begins past the Santa Fe River sink in the park and will cut-off access road to south end of the park. At 45.0 feet, Numerous walking trails in O'leno State Park are flooded on the Alachua County side of the river. Flooding begins to affect local roads north of Buzzard Roost Prairie in Columbia County. At 52.0 feet, A barn floods upstream of O'leno State park in Alachua County at this level. At 53.0 feet, Water reaches the base of the suspension bridge at the O'leno State Park.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 52.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 47.4 feet Thursday, August 15. - Flood stage is 43.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:21PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Hildreth On U.S. 129 Bridge affecting Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River near High Springs affecting Columbia and Alachua Counties.
Santa Fe River At Fort White affecting Columbia and Gilchrist Counties.
Santa Fe River Near O'Leno State Park affecting Columbia and Alachua Counties.
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Santa Fe River Near Worthington Springs affecting Alachua and Union Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road. At 21.0 feet, Homes are surrounded on River Run Road in Suwannee County. Structures flood along Santa Fe Road west of Idaho Parkway in Columbia County. At 22.0 feet, River Run Road at 29th loop floods in Suwannee County. Santa Fe Road in Columbia County is inaccessible. At 23.0 feet, Homes are inaccessible along River Run Road in Suwannee County west of 33rd Road. At 24.0 feet, Flooding expands across the area affecting numerous homes on Santa Fe Road and SW Riverside Avenue in Columbia County. Access to 29th loop in Suwannee County becomes restricted. At 26.0 feet, Significant flooding continues throughout the area. Flooded area along the Ichetucknee River expands both in Suwannee and Columbia Counties. Numerous homes are flooded at this level.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 19.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 25.9 feet Thursday, August 15. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall will continue.
* WHERE...A portion of north central North Carolina, including the following counties, Caswell, Rockingham and Stokes.
* WHEN...Until 700 AM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is occurring.

Danville, Eden, Reidsville, Wentworth, Mayodan, Madison and Yanceyville. - For flooding safety information, please visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

Suwannee River At Suwannee Springs affecting Suwannee and Hamilton Counties.
Suwannee River At White Springs affecting Columbia, Suwannee and Hamilton Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Suwannee River at White Springs.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 70.0 feet, Water reaches the top of the boat ramp at US 41 in Hamilton County. At 72.0 feet, Water reaches the top of the bank at the park at US 41 in Hamilton County. All public boat ramps between White Springs and Suwannee Springs are subject to closure. At 74.0 feet, The parking lot to the Blue Sink launch floods in Suwannee County. The area is not accessible above this level. Flooding expands into the park at US 41 in Hamilton County. At 75.0 feet, Access to White Springs Swim House is impassible. At 77.0 feet, Homes on NW Null Road in Columbia County become isolated at this level. Homes not elevated begin to flood at this level. At 79.0 feet, Water reaches the top of the bank at the Stephen F Foster State Park. Low areas within the park begin to flood at this level. At 80.0 feet, Water moves toward NW Stephen Foster Drive and begins to flood travel lanes in the 500 block in Columbia County.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 78.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 78.8 feet early Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 74.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Suwannee River at Suwannee Springs.

* IMPACTS...At 60.0 feet, Water comes over the bank at Suwannee Springs Park and begins to flood low lying areas of the park in Suwannee County. In Hamilton County, portions of SW 79th Terrace begin to flood. At 62.0 feet, In Suwannee County, the entrance to the Suwannee Springs Park floods. Deese-Howard boat ramp is inaccessible. At 63.0 feet, In Hamilton County, much of SW 79th Terrace is flooded at this level. Access to homes in the area is restricted. At 64.0 feet, Water begins to flood 91st Drive in Suwannee County. At 65.0 feet, In Hamilton County, water begins to surround residences near SW 72nd Lane and Holton Creek. Structures not elevated are subject to flooding above this level. At 66.0 feet, In Suwannee County, water begins to surround homes of 91st Drive. At 67.0 feet, In Hamilton County, several residences are surrounded by water on SW 68th Drive. Structures not elevated are prone to flooding above this level. In Suwannee County, 91st Lane is impassible above this level.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 63.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 66.7 feet Monday morning. - Flood stage is 60.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:11PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida... Georgia...
St Mary's River At Macclenny affecting Baker, Nassau and Charlton Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/wfo/JAX
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...St Mary's River at Macclenny.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Minor flooding of low lying areas and timber lands including some properties along St. Mary's River Bluff Road and the Cypress Landing Resort on the Georgia side. At 14.0 feet, Flooding of bottomlands along the river and some lower access roads including the lower half of St. Mary's River Bluff Road which cuts off 15 to 20 homes on the Georgia side. At 15.0 feet, Flooding begins to impact the lower end of Steel Bridge Road on the Florida side and cuts off access to the river gage as well as access to several homes. At 16.0 feet, Access roads on both sides of the river in Florida and Georgia are flooded, including the entire low lying stretch of St. Mary's River Bluff Road on the Georgia side which cuts off 40 to 50 homes. On the Florida side, the lower end of St. Mary's Cove Road past the public boat ramp becomes flooded and cuts off access to 20 to 30 homes. The Stokes Road Bridge over the river is generally closed due to high water. At 17.0 feet, High water on the river reaches the bottom of the Stokes Road Bridge. At 20.0 feet, High banks on the Florida side begin to overflow. Trailers and houses along the river in Baker County are endangered. Trailers and houses on the Georgia side near Stokesville are endangered.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 18.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 15.2 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Baker, FL; Nassau, FL; Charlton, GA

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued August 8 at 8:13PM EDT until August 9 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, 1 to 2 feet of inundation above ground level in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways. For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 6 to 8 feet in the surf zone. For the Beach Hazards Statement, dangerous rip currents and large breaking waves expected in the surf zone.
* WHERE...West Carteret and Coastal Onslow Counties.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, until 11 AM EDT Friday. For the High Surf Advisory, until 8 AM EDT Friday. For the Beach Hazards Statement, from 8 AM EDT Friday through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The most likely time for strong rip currents to occur is a couple hours either side of low tide, which will occur around 5:16 PM Friday.

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 8 at 8:13PM EDT until August 9 at 3:15PM EDT by NWS Charleston SC
entry.summary:
At 813 PM EDT, local law enforcement continues to report that the Cypress Lake Dam could fail at any time.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding from the imminent failure of The Cypress Lake Dam.
SOURCE...Law enforcement reported.
IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas downstream from the Cypress Lake Dam.
If the dam breaks, flash flooding will occur immediately downstream of the dam, including Cypress Lake Mobile Home Park, Dry Ranch Village and portions of Cypress Lake Road, Cypress Lake Drive and Cypress Lake Court. Flood waters would then travel south to Highway 301. If asked to evacuate from local officials, do so.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 4:02PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Pollution Advisory...in effect until 3 PM PDT Friday.
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued an air quality advisory for Jackson and Klamath counties due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in Josephine, and eastern Douglas counties through at least Friday afternoon due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM PDT FRIDAY

* WHERE...A portion of central South Carolina, including the following counties, Bamberg and Orangeburg.
* WHEN...Until 730 PM EDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Expect many areas of slow moving or standing water.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 6:37PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Newport/Morehead City NC has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in North Carolina...
N.E. Cape Fear near N.E. Cape Fear River Near Beulaville affecting Duplin County.
* WHAT...At least Moderate Flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...N.E. Cape Fear near N.E. Cape Fear River Near Beulaville.
* WHEN...From this evening until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Many acres of farmland along the river and adjacent creeks are flooded. Water may inundate portions of Hallsville Road, Blizzard Town Road, and Sarecta Road. The boat ramp area of NC 24 becomes flooded and inaccessible. At 21.0 feet, Water surrounds numerous homes and businesses along the river west of Beulaville, with some homes likely inundated. Travel along local roads becomes increasingly difficult as many small creeks and tributaries overflow onto roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 6:25 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 17.1 feet. - Forecast...No forecast is available for this location. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM THIS EVENING UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 8 at 6:28PM EDT until August 9 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of eastern North Carolina, including the following areas, Beaufort, Coastal Onslow, Duplin, East Carteret, Greene, Hatteras Island, Inland Onslow, Jones, Lenoir, Mainland Dare, Mainland Hyde, Martin, Northern Craven, Northern Outer Banks, Ocracoke Island, Pamlico, Pitt, Southern Craven, Tyrrell, Washington and West Carteret.
* WHEN...Through Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas. Extensive street flooding and flooding of creeks and rivers are possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Tropical Cyclone Debby will continue to produce periods of heavy rainfall across eastern North Carolina through Friday. Additional rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches with locally higher amounts will be possible. If these amounts materialize, there will be an increased risk of significant flooding of urban, low lying, and poor drainage areas this week. Where the heaviest rainfall rates occur, there will be the potential for flash flooding as well. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 3:22PM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
An Air Quality Alert for smoke has been issued by Southwest Clean Air Agency until 1 PM PDT Friday. Wildfires burning in the region will cause air quality to reach unhealthy for sensitive groups due to smoke.
All sensitive groups should limit spending any time outdoors. People with health conditions may have worsened symptoms. Healthy people may start to have symptoms.
Wildfire smoke can cause burning eyes, sore throat, headache, coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, and worsening of heart and lung conditions.
For current current air quality conditions, health precautions, and additional information on wildland fire smoke, visit the Southwest Clean Air Agency website at swcleanair.gov or the Washington Smoke Blog at http://wasmoke.blogspot.com. You may also contact your local air quality agency.

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM PDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued August 8 at 2:05PM PDT until August 10 at 12:00AM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
entry.summary:
The National Weather Service in Seattle has issued a Red Flag Warning for thunderstorms and gusty outflow winds, which is in effect from 10 AM Friday to midnight PDT Friday night.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 658 West Slopes of the North Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet.
* THUNDERSTORMS...Scattered thunderstorms are expected over the North Cascades with LAL of 3 during the afternoon and evening hours.
* OUTFLOW WINDS...Gusty and erratic winds are possible in the vicinity of any thunderstorms that develop.
* IMPACTS...Scattered lightning in dry fuels can cause multiple fire starts. Thunderstorms can also bring sudden sharp wind shifts on existing fires, causing rapid changes in a fire's rate of spread and direction of spread. Thunderstorm outflow winds can be a threat for several hours following the start of a new lightning-caused fire. If a fire were to begin, air quality may diminish in the surrounding area.
entry.cap:areaDesc: West Slopes of the North Cascades Generally above 1500 Feet

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 12:58PM PDT by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Pollution Advisory...in effect until 3 PM PDT Friday.
The Oregon Department of Environmental Quality issued an air quality advisory for Klamath County due to wildfires burning in the region. The DEQ also expects intermittent smoke in Jackson, Josephine, and eastern Douglas counties through at least Friday afternoon due to smoke from surrounding fires.
The wildfire smoke combined with forecast conditions will cause air quality levels to fluctuate and could be at unhealthy levels.
Smoke levels can change rapidly depending on the weather and planned burn operations. Smoke can irritate the eyes and lungs and worsen some medical conditions. People most at risk include infants and young children, people with heart or lung disease, older adults and pregnant people.
People can take the following precautions to protect their health:
- Follow local burn restrictions to prevent deteriorating air quality. - Avoid strenuous outdoor activity during periods of poor air quality. - People with heart or lung problems and young children are especially vulnerable. These people should stay indoors while smoke levels are high. - Use certified High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters in indoor heating, ventilation, cooling and air purification systems. - Avoid using wood-burning stoves and other sources of indoor smoke if possible.
For additional information...please visit the web site at https://oregonsmoke.org

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM PDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 2:37PM CDT by NWS Fort Worth TX
entry.summary:
AQAFWD
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Dallas-Fort Worth area for Friday, August 9, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone air pollution in the Dallas-Fort Worth area on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive-through lanes, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone:
Ozone: The Facts (www.tceq.texas.gov/goto/ozonefacts)
Air North Texas: (www.airnorthtexas.org)
EPA Air Now (www.airnow.gov/index.cfm?action.local_state&STATEID=45&TAB=0)
Take care of Texas (www.takecareoftexas.org)
North Central Texas Council of Governments Air Quality (www.nctcog.org/trans/air/index.asp)

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 8 at 3:22PM EDT until August 10 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of central and northern Vermont, including the following Vermont counties, Washington, Caledonia, Essex, Orleans, Eastern Chittenden, Eastern Franklin and Lamoille.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Widespread showers with embedded thunderstorms are expected across much of northern and central Vermont as the remnants of Tropical Cyclone Debby cross the region. Rainfall amounts of 1.5 to 2.5 inches with locally higher possible will cause streams and possibly rivers to rise sharply, and flooding may occur.
Damaged infrastructure and clogged culverts and drainage ditches may be especially vulnerable to additional flood damage.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Orleans; Essex; Lamoille; Caledonia; Washington; Eastern Franklin; Eastern Chittenden

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 10:44AM AKDT until August 10 at 12:45PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
Heavy rain has been failing over the Lake Creek, Skwentna, and Yentna river basins for the past 48 hours with areas receiving 2-4 inches of rain.
...REPLACES FLOOD ADVISORY...
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Lake Creek, Yentna and Skwentna Rivers.
* WHEN...Until 1245 PM AKDT Saturday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1036 AM AKDT, River levels have risen approximately 4 and 6 feet on the Yentna and Skwentna Rivers since Tuesday with water reported overbank on Lake Creek near the confluence of the Yentna River and with widespread flooding of low lying areas.
The heavy rain is expected to taper today with and additional 0.5 to 2 inches possible. Rivers will continue to rise as high water works its way downstream. Water levels on the Yentna, Skwentna River are expected to crest tomorrow with an additional 1 to 2 foot rise possible.
- Http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

* WHEN...For the High Rip Current Risk, through Friday evening. For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 6 AM Friday to 6 AM EDT Saturday. For the High Surf Advisory, from 8 AM to 8 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of lots, parks, and roads with only isolated road closures expected. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, the main impacts from minor coastal flooding are expected along Barnegat Bay, especially near Mantoloking, where persistent southerly winds will trap high water from draining at high tide. High surf may result in sand dune breaching and beach erosion near the times of high tide.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued August 8 at 12:04PM MDT until August 9 at 12:00AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of north central and northeast New Mexico, including the following areas, in north central New Mexico, East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains and Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains. In northeast New Mexico, Far Northeast Highlands, Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass and Northeast Highlands.
* WHEN...Until midnight MDT tonight.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Numerous thunderstorms are forecast this afternoon and evening as disturbances aloft cross a moist backdoor front banked up against the east slopes of the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. Some of the stronger thunderstorms will be capable of producing torrential rainfall at rates near 2 inches per hour. Burn scars, urban areas, and places with complex terrain will be most susceptible to rapid runoff and flash flooding today. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 1:50PM EDT until August 9 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is occurring.
* WHERE...Portions of the southern and eastern Piedmont, Sandhills, and southern and central Coastal Plain of central North Carolina.
* WHEN...Until 200 PM EDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Rivers, creeks and streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Some roads may remain closed or impassible into the nighttime hours.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 143 PM EDT, local law enforcement reported flooding in the warned area. Between 2 and 6 inches of rain have fallen. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Raleigh, Durham, Fayetteville, Cary, Chapel Hill, Goldsboro, Sanford, Laurinburg, Albemarle, Southern Pines, Smithfield, Rockingham, Clinton, Wadesboro, Raeford, Mount Olive, Pittsboro, Lillington, Troy and Carthage. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued August 8 at 1:34PM EDT until August 9 at 1:30PM EDT by NWS Tallahassee FL
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Madison County Emergency Management continued to report gradually rising water levels in southeastern Madison County just south of Interstate 10 east of County Road 360, especially in the vicinity of I-10 and Exit 258 due to past heavy rainfall from Hurricane Debby.
* WHERE...Southeast Madison County in the Florida Big Bend
* WHEN...Until at least Friday afternoon
* IMPACTS...Water levels are likely to continue to rise and gradually spread to areas south and east across the county as localized runoff continues. Numerous roads are flooded, along with a campground near Exit 258 being significantly impacted. Some roads are already or will soon become impassable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 122 PM EDT, Flooding will likely persist into the weekend due to more than 12 inches of rain that occurred across the warning area from Hurricane Debby. With high groundwater levels, locations near small creeks, springs, or sinks in Southeast Madison County could be prone to flooding on relatively short notice. If you live in an area prone to flooding, take action to protect property. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Hopewell. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 7:21AM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
AQAPSR
The Arizona Department of Environmental Quality (ADEQ) has extended an Ozone High Pollution Advisory for the Phoenix Metro Area through Friday.
This means that forecast weather conditions combined with existing ozone levels are expected to result in local maximum 8-hour ozone concentrations that pose a health risk. Adverse health effects increase as air quality deteriorates.
Ozone is an air contaminant which can cause breathing difficulties for children, older adults, as well as persons with respiratory problems. A decrease in physical activity is recommended.
You are urged to car pool, telecommute or use mass transit. The use of gasoline-powered equipment should be reduced or done late in the day.
For details on this High Pollution Advisory, visit the ADEQ internet site at www.azdeq.gov/forecast/phoenix or call 602-771-2300.

cap:parameter.value: OZONE HIGH POLLUTION ADVISORY FOR MARICOPA COUNTY INCLUDING THE PHOENIX METRO AREA THROUGH FRIDAY

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued August 8 at 9:05AM EDT until August 10 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
entry.summary:
FFWILM
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a
* Flash Flood Warning for... Central Marlboro County in northeastern South Carolina...
* Until noon EDT Saturday.
* At 905 AM EDT, Crooked Creek at North Marlboro Street is beginning to come out of its banks at a gage level of about 19 feet. Modeling of water levels incorporating rainfall from Tropical Storm Debby, indicates the creek could rise another 4 to 6 feet by the 10th.
HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding resulting from runoff from recent rainfall.
SOURCE...Gauge reported and modeling.
IMPACT...Potentially life threatening flash flooding of along the creek of area streets.
* Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Bennettsville.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 8 at 12:46AM PDT by NWS Pendleton OR
entry.summary:
Oregon Department of Environmental Quality has issued an Air Quality Advisory...IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 PM PDT FRIDAY.
A Smoke Air Quality Advisory has been issued. Wildfires burning in the region combined with forecasted conditions will cause air quality to reach unhealthy levels.
Pollutants in smoke can cause burning eyes...runny nose...aggravate heart and lung diseases...and aggravate other serious health problems. Limit outdoor activities and keep children indoors if it is smoky. Please follow medical advice if you have a heart or lung condition.
For additional information...please visit the Web site at http://www.oregon.gov/DEQ

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued August 7 at 10:40AM PDT by NWS Spokane WA
entry.summary:
An Air Quality Alert has been issued by the following agencies:
Washington Department of Ecology Colville Confederated Tribes
An Air Quality Alert continues for all of Okanogan County until further notice, due to expected smoke from nearby and regional wildfires. Particulate matter (PM2.5) may reach Unhealthy and Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups levels.
Health Impacts and Recommended Actions: When air quality is Unhealthy, everyone should reduce exposure. When air quality is Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups, sensitive groups should take steps to reduce exposure. Limit time outside, avoid strenuous outdoor activity, and follow tips for cleaner indoor air. Everyone should watch for symptoms as a sign to reduce exposure.
Agricultural and outdoor burning restrictions are in effect.
